claims.text: The climate has changed remarkably little over the past 30 years.
The IPCC acknowledged in its own 2007 report that long-term prediction of future climate states is not possible.
Group one believes that recent climate change is primarily due to man’s burning of fossil fuels.

The IPCC acknowledged in its own 2007 report that long-term prediction of future climate states is not possible.
Group one believes that recent climate change is primarily due to man’s burning of fossil fuels.

claim_reports.claim_text: The climate has changed remarkably little over the past 30 years.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence from multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and climate data reports, consistently shows that global temperatures have risen significantly over the past 30 years, directly contradicting the claim that the climate has changed remarkably little during this period.

refutes.title: Climate change: global temperature
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that global temperatures have risen significantly over the past 30 years, contradicting the claim that climate has changed remarkably little during this period.
refutes.snippet: Earth's temperature has risen by an average of 0.11° Fahrenheit (0.06° Celsius) per decade since 1850, or about 2° F in total.

refutes.title: Evidence - NASA Science
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly indicates that the climate has changed significantly over the past 30 years, with the period from 1983 to 2012 being the warmest 30-year period in the last 800 years. This contradicts the claim that the climate has changed remarkably little during this time.
refutes.snippet: Earth's climate has changed throughout history. Just in the last 800000 years, there have been eight cycles of ice ages and warmer periods, ...

refutes.title: World of Change: Global Temperatures - NASA Science
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that global temperatures have increased significantly over the past 30 years, with the majority of warming occurring since 1975, contradicting the claim that climate has changed remarkably little during this period.
refutes.snippet: The average global temperature has increased by a little more than 1 degree Celsius since 1880. Two-thirds of the warming has occurred since 1975.

refutes.title: Updated 30-year reference period reflects changing climate
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the climate has changed significantly over the past 30 years, with the period from 1983 to 2012 being the warmest 30-year period in the last 800 to 1400 years. This contradicts the claim that the climate has changed remarkably little during this time.
refutes.snippet: The South and Southwest are considerably warmer. Normals were also generally warmer across the West and along the East Coast. Precipitation-wise, the Southwest ...

refutes.title: CO₂ and Greenhouse Gas Emissions - Our World in Data
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that global temperatures have been rising significantly, with an increase of at least 1.1° Celsius since 1880, and the majority of this warming has occurred since 1975, contradicting the claim that the climate has changed remarkably little over the past 30 years.
refutes.snippet: Human greenhouse gas emissions have increased global average temperatures · Global emissions have increased rapidly over the last 50 years and have not yet ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The IPCC acknowledged in its own 2007 report that long-term prediction of future climate states is not possible.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the claim. While some sources indicate that the IPCC acknowledges limitations in long-term climate predictions, they do not explicitly state that such predictions are impossible. The USA Today fact check and Climate Central article support the idea of uncertainty in long-term forecasts, while the IPCC's own documents highlight limitations without declaring impossibility.

supports.title: Fact check: Climate models reliable, IPCC statement misrepresented
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the IPCC acknowledges limitations in predicting specific climate events and states, particularly regarding long-term forecasts of phenomena like El Niño, which aligns with the claim that long-term predictions are not possible.
supports.snippet: The IPCC statement accurately asserts that "climate states" such as weather events or the occurrence of an El Niño cannot be predicted very far in advance.

supports.title: IPCC Predictions: Then Versus Now - Climate Central
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the limitations of IPCC models and acknowledges that they have consistently underestimated real-world observations, indicating that long-term predictions of future climate states are fraught with uncertainty.
supports.snippet: Projection: The IPCC's 2007 assessment projected a worst-case temperature rise of 4.3° to 11.5°F, with a high probability of 7.2°F. IPCC ...

mixed.title: [PDF] Long-term Climate Change: Projections, Commitments and ...
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that while the IPCC acknowledges uncertainties in climate modeling, it does not explicitly state that long-term predictions of future climate states are impossible. Instead, it highlights that projections have consistently underestimated real-world observations due to unforeseen factors, suggesting limitations rather than outright impossibility in making long-term predictions.
mixed.snippet: IPCC, 2007: Climate Change 2007: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of. Working Group I to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental. Panel ...

unclear.evidence_summary: The report: • evaluates evidence that recent observed changes in climate have already affected a variety of physical and biological systems and concludes that ...
unclear.snippet: The report: • evaluates evidence that recent observed changes in climate have already affected a variety of physical and biological systems and concludes that ...

unclear.snippet: This Synthesis Report with its Summary for Policymakers is the fourth and final part of the Fourth Assessment Report. (AR4) of the Intergovernmental Panel on ...

unclear.title: [PDF] Climate Change 2007: Synthesis Report - Summary for Policymakers
unclear.evidence_summary: It provides an integrated view of climate change as the final part of the IPCC's Fourth. Assessment Report (AR4). A complete elaboration of the Topics covered ...
unclear.snippet: It provides an integrated view of climate change as the final part of the IPCC's Fourth. Assessment Report (AR4). A complete elaboration of the Topics covered ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Group one believes that recent climate change is primarily due to man’s burning of fossil fuels.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the claim that recent climate change is primarily due to man’s burning of fossil fuels. While several high-reliability sources, including NASA and Berkeley, support the claim by stating that fossil fuel combustion is a primary driver of climate change, there are also high-reliability reports indicating that the EPA has removed references to fossil fuels from its website, which raises concerns about the acknowledgment of this link. This contradiction suggests a lack of consensus.

refutes.title: EPA eliminates mention of fossil fuels in website on warming's ...
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the EPA has removed references to fossil fuels as a primary driver of climate change from its website, which contradicts the claim that recent climate change is primarily due to man’s burning of fossil fuels. The article highlights concerns from climate scientists about the misleading nature of these changes and the implications for public understanding of climate science.
refutes.snippet: WASHINGTON (AP) — The Environmental Protection Agency has removed any mention of fossil fuels — the main driver of global warming — from its ...

refutes.title: EPA erases references to human-caused climate change from ...
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the EPA has removed references to human-caused climate change, particularly the role of fossil fuels, from its website, which suggests a denial of the established link between human activities and climate change.
refutes.snippet: “Greenhouse gases come from a variety of human activities, including burning fossil fuels for heat and energy, clearing forests, fertilizing ...

supports.title: Burning of fossil fuels - Understanding Global Change
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly states that the burning of fossil fuels is the primary cause of current climate change, as it emits greenhouse gases that trap heat in the atmosphere.
supports.snippet: The burning of fossil fuels is the primary cause of current climate change, altering the Earth's ecosystems and causing human and environmental health problems.

supports.title: The Causes of Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that burning fossil fuels emits greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, which trap heat in the atmosphere and contribute to climate change, supporting the claim that recent climate change is primarily due to human activities involving fossil fuels.
supports.snippet: This increase happens because the coal or oil burning process combines carbon with oxygen in the air to make CO2.

supports.title: EPA climate page omits human role, draws criticism - The Hill
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that there is a scientific consensus that climate change is primarily driven by human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, despite recent changes to the EPA's website that downplay this connection. Critics of the EPA's alterations emphasize that these changes misrepresent the overwhelming scientific evidence linking human activity to climate change.
supports.snippet: There is a scientific consensus that climate change is primarily driven by human activity, including the burning of fossil fuels. However, ...

supports.title: Fossil fuels and climate change: the facts - ClientEarth
supports.evidence_summary: The article states that burning fossil fuels emits greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, which trap heat in the atmosphere and contribute to climate change, supporting the claim that recent climate change is primarily due to fossil fuel combustion.
supports.snippet: When fossil fuels are burned, they release large amounts of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, into the air. Greenhouse gases trap heat in our atmosphere, ...

transcript_data.text: I’m an atmospheric physicist. I’ve published more than 200 scientific papers. For 30 years I taught at MIT, during which time the climate has changed remarkably little. But the cry of “global warming” has grown ever more shrill. In fact, it seems that the less the climate changes, the louder the voices of the climate alarmists get. So, let’s clear the air and create a more accurate picture of where we really stand on the issue of global warming or, as it is now called -- climate change. There are basically three groups of people dealing with this issue. Groups one and two are scientists. Group three consists mostly, at its core, of politicians, environmentalists and media. Group one is associated with the scientific part of the United Nation’s International Panel on Climate Change or IPCC (Working Group 1). These are scientists who mostly believe that recent climate change is primarily due to man’s burning of fossil fuels -- oil, coal and natural gas. This releases C02, carbon dioxide, into the atmosphere and, they believe, this might eventually dangerously heat the planet. Group two is made up of scientists who don’t see this as an especially serious problem. This is the group I belong to. We’re usually referred to as skeptics. We note that there are many reasons why the climate changes -- the sun, clouds, oceans, the orbital variations of the earth, as well as a myriad of other inputs. None of these is fully understood, and there is no evidence that CO2 emissions are the dominant factor. But actually there is much agreement between both groups of scientists. The following are such points of agreement: 1) The climate is always changing. 2) CO2 is a greenhouse gas without which life on earth is not possible, but adding it to the atmosphere should lead to some warming. 3) Atmospheric levels of CO2 have been increasing since the end of the Little Ice Age in the 19th century. 4) Over this period (the past two centuries), the global mean temperature has increased slightly and erratically by about 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit or one degree Celsius; but only since the 1960’s have man’s greenhouse emissions been sufficient to play a role. 5) Given the complexity of climate, no confident prediction about future global mean temperature or its impact can be made. The IPCC, acknowledged in its own 2007 report that “The long-term prediction of future climate states is not possible.” Most importantly, the scenario that the burning of fossil fuels leads to catastrophe isn’t part of what either group asserts. So why are so many people worried, indeed, panic stricken about this issue. Here’s where Group Three comes in -- the politicians, environmentalists, and media. Global Warming Alarmism provides them, more than any other issue, with the things they most want: For politicians it’s money and power. For environmentalists it’s money for their organizations and confirmation of their near religious devotion to the idea that man is a destructive force acting upon nature. And for the media it’s ideology, money, and headlines -- doomsday scenarios sell. Meanwhile, over the last decade, scientists outside of climate physics have jumped on the bandwagon, publishing papers blaming global warming for everything from acne to the Syrian civil war. And, crony capitalists have eagerly grabbed for the subsidies that governments have so lavishly provided. Unfortunately, group three is winning the argument because they have drowned out the serious debate that should be going on. But while politicians, environmentalists and media types can waste a lot of money and scare a lot of people, they won’t be able to bury the truth. The climate will have the final word on that. I’m Richard Lindzen, emeritus professor of Atmospheric Sciences at MIT, for PragerUniversity.

segments.text:
I’m an atmospheric physicist. I’ve published
more than 200 scientific papers. For 30 years

I taught at MIT, during which time the climate
has changed remarkably little. But the cry

of “global warming” has grown ever more
shrill. In fact, it seems that the less the

climate changes, the louder the voices of
the climate alarmists get. So, let’s clear

the air and create a more accurate picture
of where we really stand on the issue of global

warming or, as it is now called -- climate
change.

There are basically three groups of people
dealing with this issue. Groups one and two

are scientists. Group three consists mostly,
at its core, of politicians, environmentalists

and media.
Group one is associated with the scientific

part of the United Nation’s International
Panel on Climate Change or IPCC (Working Group 1).

These are scientists who mostly believe
that recent climate change is primarily due

to man’s burning of fossil fuels -- oil,
coal and natural gas. This releases C02, carbon dioxide,

into the atmosphere and, they believe,
this might eventually dangerously heat the planet.
Group two is made up of scientists who don’t see this as an especially serious problem.
This is the group I belong to. We’re usually referred to as skeptics. We note that there are many reasons why the

climate changes -- the sun, clouds, oceans,
the orbital variations of the earth,

as well as a myriad of other inputs. None of these
is fully understood, and there is no evidence

that CO2 emissions are the dominant factor.
But actually there is much agreement between

both groups of scientists. The following are
such points of agreement:

1) The climate is always changing.
2) CO2 is a greenhouse gas without which life

on earth is not possible, but adding it to
the atmosphere should lead to some warming.

3) Atmospheric levels of CO2 have been increasing
since the end of the Little Ice Age in the 19th century.
4) Over this period (the past two centuries),

the global mean temperature has increased
slightly and erratically by about 1.8 degrees

Fahrenheit or one degree Celsius; but only
since the 1960’s have man’s greenhouse

emissions been sufficient to play a role.
5) Given the complexity of climate, no confident

prediction about future global mean temperature
or its impact can be made. The IPCC, acknowledged

in its own 2007 report that “The long-term
prediction of future climate states is not possible.”
Most importantly, the scenario that the burning of fossil fuels
leads to catastrophe isn’t part of what either group asserts.

So why are so many people worried, indeed, panic
stricken about this issue.
Here’s where Group Three comes in -- the politicians, environmentalists, and media.

Global Warming Alarmism provides them, more
than any other issue, with the things they

most want: For politicians it’s money and
power. For environmentalists it’s money

for their organizations and confirmation of
their near religious devotion to the idea

that man is a destructive force acting upon
nature. And for the media it’s ideology,

money, and headlines -- doomsday scenarios
sell.

Meanwhile, over the last decade, scientists
outside of climate physics have jumped on

the bandwagon, publishing papers blaming global
warming for everything from acne to the Syrian

civil war. And, crony capitalists have eagerly
grabbed for the subsidies that governments

have so lavishly provided.
Unfortunately, group three is winning the

argument because they have drowned out the
serious debate that should be going on.

But while politicians, environmentalists and
media types can waste a lot of money and scare

a lot of people, they won’t be able to bury
the truth. The climate will have the final word on that.
I’m Richard Lindzen, emeritus professor of Atmospheric Sciences at MIT, for PragerUniversity.
